User Viewing This document defines an XMPP protocol extension for communicating information about the television shows, movies, or other videos that a user watches. &LEGALNOTICE; 0197 Experimental Standards Track Standards

section1.p: &xep0060; and &xep0163; can be used to publish a wide variety of "extended presence" information about users. This document specifies an extended presence payload format that communicates information about the television shows, movies, or other videos that a user watches. This information may be of interest to a user's contacts and can also be used in social networking applications (e.g., IPTV systems).

section2.p: Information about video viewing is provided by the user (or automated integration with video systems) and is propagated on the network by the user's client. The information container for video viewing data is a <video/> element that is qualified by the 'urn:xmpp:viewing:0' namespace. The video information itself is provided as the XML character data of the following children of the <video/> element:

tr.td: The cast members of the program
Trace Beaulieu, Frank Conniff, Joel Hodgson, Jim Mallon, Kevin Murphy, Michael J. Nelson, Mary Jo Pehl
The name of the channel showing the program
The duration of the program (in seconds)
The end time of the program
The episode number of the program
The start time of the program
The type of the sub-program (e.g., outtakes on an extended DVD)
A URI for the video or relevant service
A user's free-form comments about the program
This is one of my favorite episodes! MST3K forever!
The user's personal rating of the program (on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being highest)

section2.p: NOTE: The datatypes specified above are defined in &w3xmlschema2;.

When a user starts watching a video, its client may publish that fact to a PEP node whose NodeID is "urn:xmpp:viewing:0" &NSNOTE; or to a generic pubsub node. Because viewing information is not pure presence information and can change independently of the user's availability, it SHOULD NOT be provided as an extension to the &PRESENCE; stanza type.
section2.example: <iq type='set' from='stpeter@jabber.org/work' id='viewing1'> <pubsub xmlns='http://jabber.org/protocol/pubsub'> <publish node='urn:xmpp:viewing:0'> <item id='8eaa8ae16651455376dab4eae45772337e9ec372'> <video xmlns='urn:xmpp:viewing:0'> <name>Mystery Science Theater 3000</name> <episode>807</episode> <description>Terror From The Year 5000</description> <uri>http://www.mst3kinfo.com/</uri> </video> </item> </publish> </pubsub> </iq>
section2.p: The viewing information is then delivered to all subscribers:

example.caption: Viewing Information is Delivered to All Subscribers

section2.example: <message from='stpeter@jabber.org' to='maineboy@jabber.org'> <event xmlns='http://jabber.org/protocol/pubsub#event'> <items node='urn:xmpp:viewing:0'> <item id='8eaa8ae16651455376dab4eae45772337e9ec372'> <video xmlns='urn:xmpp:viewing:0'> <name>Mystery Science Theater 3000</name> <episode>807</episode> <description>Terror From The Year 5000</description> <uri>http://www.mst3kinfo.com/</uri> </video> </item> </items> </event> </message>
section2.p: When the user stops watching the video, the user's client SHOULD send an empty <video/> element with the same ItemID:

example.caption: Stop Information is Delivered to All Subscribers

section1.p: The videos that a user watches may be sensitive. A client MUST provide a way for a user to configure which videos or types of videos will not be published (e.g., via user preferences).
This document requires no interaction with &IANA;.
